item.title: Freddie Mercury's voice focus of new study
item.description: Freddie Mercury's voice was easy come, easy go, little high, little low, and now a group of researchers have delved into how amazing it was.
item.ExtractedText:
Facebook Twitter Instagram
Freddie Mercury's voice focus of new study Updated 0416 GMT (1216 HKT) April 21, 2016 Researchers call their study of Freddie Mercury's vocals a work of "fan-science." Story highlights The Queen lead singer was a master at modulating his voice, the study found Mercury died in 1991 of AIDS-related complications (CNN) Freddie Mercury's voice was easy come, easy go, little high, little low, and now a group of researchers have delved into how amazing it was. The study, " Freddie Mercury -- acoustic analysis of speaking fundamental frequency, vibrato, and subharmonics," was recently published in the journal "Logopedics Phoniatrics Vocology" and looked at the Queen front man's vocal abilities. JUST WATCHED MUST WATCH Larynx in action: 'Fascinating, gross' 02:41 The team of Austrian, Czech and Swedish authors used archival recordings to delve into the sound of the man whose voice has been described as "a force of nature with the velocity of a hurricane." Quiz: What does your favorite music say about you? "Freddie Mercury was one of the twentieth century's best-known singers of commercial contemporary music," the study states. "This study presents an acoustical analysis of his voice production and singing style, based on perceptual and quantitative analysis of publicly available sound recordings." Read More 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV Actor Charlie Sheen told NBC's "Today" show on Nov. 17, 2015 that he was diagnosed as HIV-positive about four years earlier, and that a few people who knew it demanded money from him to keep the secret. Hide Caption 1 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV Actor Rock Hudson revealed that he had AIDS after he collapsed while seeking treatment in France. He died a few months later, on October 2, 1985 . Hide Caption 2 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV 3 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV NBA legend Earvin "Magic" Johnson called a press conference on November 7, 1991, to announce that he would be retiring from professional basketball after learning that he was HIV-positive. Hide Caption 4 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV American actor Anthony Perkins died in 1992 without revealing that he had AIDS. With his permission, his widow, Berry Berenson, shared his struggle with the disease after he died. Hide Caption 5 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV Actor Robert Reed, who starred as father Mike Brady in "The Brady Bunch," never came out as gay or HIV-positive in his lifetime . After he died of cancer in 1992, his death certificate included HIV as a contributing factor. Hide Caption 6 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV Professional tennis player Arthur Ashe revealed in 1992 that he had AIDS . Ashe, who said he probably had contracted the virus from a blood transfusion, died in 1993 . Hide Caption 7 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV When "The Real World: San Francisco" cast member Pedro Zamora shared his HIV/AIDS struggle on the MTV reality show, he educated the MTV generation about living with the disease. Zamora died in November 1994. Hide Caption 8 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV Olympic diver Greg Louganis revealed his HIV-positive diagnosis in a 1995 memoir, "Breaking the Surface." He says he faced some backlash but being open was the best thing for him. "My being HIV-positive doesn't define who I am," he told CNN. Hide Caption 9 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV Before he died in 1995, rapper Eazy-E, whose real name was Eric Wright, revealed that he was ill with AIDS. "I'm not saying this because I'm looking for a soft cushion wherever I'm heading," Wright said in a statement. "I just feel I've got thousands and thousands of young fans that have to learn about what's real when it comes to AIDS." Hide Caption 10 of 11 11 photos: Celebrities and HIV A former child star of the television sitcom "Who's the Boss?" actor Danny Pintauro knew he wasn't facing an automatic death sentence when he found out he was HIV positive in March 2003. Pintauro, who came out in 1997 and got married last year, shared his HIV status with Oprah Winfrey in September 2015 . "It's just a big deal, you know?" he said. Hide Caption 11 of 11 The study found that Mercury, who died in 1991 from AIDS-related complications, was a master at modulating his voice. The findings included evidence that Mercury was using "subharmonics" by vibrating his ventricular folds, a technique usually found only in Tuvan throat singers. Beardyman: The man who can make any noise "Perceptually, Freddie Mercury's irregular (and typically faster) vibrato is clearly audible in the sustained notes of famous songs such as 'Bohemian Rhapsody' (A Night at the Opera) or 'We Are the Champions' (News of the World), and it appears to be one of the hallmarks of his vocal style," the study says. The research comes on the heels of the news that a notebook belonging to Mercury, filled with lyrics to 19 songs, is set to go to auction in June.
